update.description:
Another alternative to fix issue #186.

* Removed all collisions from walkway models
* Ported walkways from model database to this repo
* The world generator script now generates a polyline collision for the whole walkway at once

![walk.png](https://bitbucket.org/repo/xEbAAe/images/3690080157-walk.png)

* It seems to work well on the great majority of cases, but the triangulation fails for some specific cases. For example, using seed 7 to generate the world, it fails because of this region:

![failgts.png](https://bitbucket.org/repo/xEbAAe/images/1169123567-failgts.png)

* For all the existing worlds, the only one which failed was `unique_task2`, so I generated it with a new seed.
update.title: Generate a single polyline walkway path collision
update.reason: Polylines have worse contacts than boxes and should be avoided as much as possible

pull_request.title: Generate a single polyline walkway path collision

pullrequest.title: Generate a single polyline walkway path collision

content.raw:
As I think about it, it's possible that static collisions aren't checked against each other. So there is probably only a performance impact if a dynamic object enters the bounding box of the static object. At any rate, I didn't notice an appreciable difference in the real-time factor for either world, so this issue probably isn't that big of a deal.

Boxes should probably be preferred, with extruded polylines to prevent box overlap.
content.html:
As I think about it, it's possible that static collisions aren't checked against each other. So there is probably only a performance impact if a dynamic object enters the bounding box of the static object. At any rate, I didn't notice an appreciable difference in the real-time factor for either world, so this issue probably isn't that big of a deal.

Boxes should probably be preferred, with extruded polylines to prevent box overlap.

pull_request.title: Generate a single polyline walkway path collision

pullrequest.title: Generate a single polyline walkway path collision

content.raw:
Thanks for taking a look at both PRs.

I think I see your point about the collision detection. Let me see if I understand:

1. During the broad phase, every bounding box is checked against each other. 
1. The more individual collisions, the worse is the performance of this phase, because they all need to be checked against each other.
1. More overlapping bounding boxes on this phase makes the next phase worse, because there are more individual pairs to check in detail.

So the single collision approach improves point 2, but has the potential of making point 3 worse.

The only bounding boxes which may overlap with the large walkway which wouldn't otherwise are rocks and other static objects on the ground, right? I feel like we should remove collisions for those anyway.

In any case, as I said above, if polylines have a poorer result than boxes, we should keep them to only where absolutely necessary (i.e. pull request #97)
content.html:
Thanks for taking a look at both PRs.

I think I see your point about the collision detection. Let me see if I understand:

  1. During the broad phase, every bounding box is checked against each other.
  2. The more individual collisions, the worse is the performance of this phase, because they all need to be checked against each other.
  3. More overlapping bounding boxes on this phase makes the next phase worse, because there are more individual pairs to check in detail.

So the single collision approach improves point 2, but has the potential of making point 3 worse.

The only bounding boxes which may overlap with the large walkway which wouldn't otherwise are rocks and other static objects on the ground, right? I feel like we should remove collisions for those anyway.

In any case, as I said above, if polylines have a poorer result than boxes, we should keep them to only where absolutely necessary (i.e. pull request #97)

pullrequest.title: Generate a single polyline walkway path collision

content.raw:
With decades of experience in software I know the effort by the entire competition software team has been amazing. I may complain (ME!!??) at certain points but know exactly what you are going through. Most of my work was in embedded systems. The software we produced was always 'late'. The major reason we were 'late' was the hardware was always late. But nobody seemed to correlate that with why the software got delayed. Not to mention all the simple, one-off software I had to write to demonstrate to the hardware guys where that line that was supposed to be high was actually low. "Fix it in software" was the response. Then in next version of the hardware they would fix it. Now the software had to determine the version of hardware to do the right thing.

Hope some of you will be at JSC at the end of the month. Would like to shake your hand or even buy you a libation. 
This reminds me of those situations. Both teams doing their best but it's the nature of the beast.
content.html:
With decades of experience in software I know the effort by the entire competition software team has been amazing. I may complain (ME!!??) at certain points but know exactly what you are going through. Most of my work was in embedded systems. The software we produced was always 'late'. The major reason we were 'late' was the hardware was always late. But nobody seemed to correlate that with why the software got delayed. Not to mention all the simple, one-off software I had to write to demonstrate to the hardware guys where that line that was supposed to be high was actually low. "Fix it in software" was the response. Then in next version of the hardware they would fix it. Now the software had to determine the version of hardware to do the right thing.

Hope some of you will be at JSC at the end of the month. Would like to shake your hand or even buy you a libation. This reminds me of those situations. Both teams doing their best but it's the nature of the beast.

content.raw: I guess the take away is: we should use box collisions as much as possible, and polylines only when strictly necessary.
content.html: I guess the take away is: we should use box collisions as much as possible, and polylines only when strictly necessary.

content.raw: This is also a problem for pull request #97 then, right? I guess it's at least better than the collision z fighting?

pullrequest.title: Generate a single polyline walkway path collision

content.raw: Also, having a large trimesh may lead to a large bounding box, which reduces the effectiveness of broadphase collision pruning. I'm inclined to lean towards pull request #97, though I am amazed by how quickly you generated this.
content.html: Also, having a large trimesh may lead to a large bounding box, which reduces the effectiveness of broadphase collision pruning. I'm inclined to lean towards pull request #97, though I am amazed by how quickly you generated this.

content.raw:
It looks like there are similar issues between standing on adjacent boxes and standing on adjacent triangles in an extruded polyline.

![auto_poly.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/xEbAAe/images/6770302-auto_poly.png)
content.html: It looks like there are similar issues between standing on adjacent boxes and standing on adjacent triangles in an extruded polyline.
